## Expectations Based on the CLT
<img src="http://derekogle.com/NCMTH107/modules/zimgs/computer-1.jpg" alt="Simulations" class="img-right">

Repeat [Class Exercise 2](SamplingDist_CE2.html) for the two additional situations below.

----

## Situation 2
Suppose the population has the characteristics shown in the figure below.

```{r Sit2, echo=FALSE, fig.width=3.25,fig.height=3,par2=TRUE}
shape1 <- 1; shape2 <- 5
x <- seq(0,0.95,0.05)
y <- round(1000*stats::dbeta(x,shape1,shape2),0)
x <- rep(x, y)
title.popn <- substitute(paste(mu,"=",muval,", ",sigma,"=",sigmaval),
                         list(muval=formatC(shape1/(shape1+shape2),
                                            format="f",digits=2),
                              sigmaval=formatC(sqrt((shape1*      shape2)/(((shape1+shape2)^2)*(shape1+shape2+1))),
                                               format="f",digits=3)))
old.par <- par(mar=c(3,2,2.25,1),mgp=c(1.7,0.4,0),tcl=-0.2,yaxs="i")
hist(x,freq=FALSE,breaks=seq(0,1,0.05),yaxt="n",xlab="Variable (X)",
     ylab="",main="",right=FALSE,col="gray90")
mtext("Population Distribution",3,line=1.3)
mtext(title.popn,3,line=0.1)
mtext("Frequency of Individuals",2,line=0.1)
par(old.par)
```

1. What is the shape, center, and dispersion of this population?
2. What would you expect, based on the CLT, the sampling distribution of the sample means to look like for n=10, 25, and 50. Record your expectations in the appropriate cells of a table like that above.

## Situation 3

